titleStmt.title: Letter from Amy Lowell to Richard Aldington, April 17, 1916
titleStmt.author: Amy Lowell

physDesc.p: The letter consists of three sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of the first two and one side of the last. At the top of each page except the first is a page number in the left corner and the date on the right side underneath the margin. Every other page has “R.A.” typed in the upper right corner. There is a watermark on the paper that reads “Berkshire Linen U.S.A.” There is also a Certificate of Issue dated April 20, 1916 that comes from the State Street Trust Co. in Boston, MA. It is issued for cheque number 1359 and says “on London for F 2-1-6”. The amount is for ten dollars. The certificate appears to have an orange wave pattern on the paper and has two perforated edges, the left and bottom sides. On the back side of this certificate is a hand-written note reading, “To Richard Aldington, Esq. First $10 on acct. royalties from E.R. Brown.”

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I received your nice long letter this morning, and very glad indeed I was to get it. It is ages since I had heard from you or Hilda, and I began to think you had both died!

I am having a hard time to get that money out of Brown, as you thought I should have. As I told you in my last letter, I finally had to resort to my lawyer, who in this case was my brother-in-law. As he failed to produce anything, on my return from Chicago I took the matter again into my own hands, with the result that Brown expressed his willingness to pay as soon as he could, and sent me ten dollars, which I have turned into an English draft and am sending you enclosed. I shall get the other twenty out of him in time, I have no doubt; but it takes a little time, for the boy is not only unbusinesslike, but very poor.

It was awfully sweet of you to mind Middleton Murray’s article in the Daily News and the Times, against “Six French Poets”. I had already gathered that they were the same man, from the similarity of the remarks and style. Some of the English criticisms have been good, like the “Observer” and the “New Witness”; others have been bad. But one and all have accorded me really a great deal of space, and the English consignment of 250 copies was sold out almost immediately and another consignment sent for. The entire first edition has gone, the book has been out of print for a month, and we are rushing ahead a second edition as fast as possible. But the numerous printers’ errors in the first edition has made the revising of this second one extremely arduous, and I do not think it will be on the market yet for a couple of weeks, at any rate. I will send you one as soon as it comes out, because I would rather have you have a correct copy than the singularly incorrect one you have now.

Theodore Stanton, who writes the American Rubric in the “Mercure”, has come to America on account of the war, and I spent an hour and a half with him the other day in New York. He is an amiable old gentleman, rather weak, and I believe he means to keep up with the movements of the day. I told him our sorrows in regard to Remy de Gourmont, and how I feared it might affect the article in the “Mercure” which he had promised you to get in. I do not think Mr. Stanton has any authority to get things in or take things out, but he was very much interested, and asked me to send him copies of all three of the “Imagist Anthologies”, as he wanted to put a notice about them in the “Mercure”. He is only allowed such a small space that he cannot say much in his notices except a mere statement – but I thought a statement was better than nothing.

The new “Anthology” is coming along very well. They expect to have it out on the 29th of April. I have already corrected the proofs, and if they do not delay fearfully, it should be on the market by that time.

Fletcher was in New York the other day when I was, and saw quite a little of Kreymborg. He feels exactly as I do about it – we think there is very little future for that crowd, and we are very glad that we withdrew ourselves from “Others.”
I am through my lectures for this year, and am about to settle down and write steadily, as my new book is coming out next Autumn.

You sound very cozy in your cottage, but I should think it might be a bit lonely. But then, I confess to being a city dweller myself – or a suburban dweller, as I am. I do not like the real country for any length of time.
Fletcher has decided that Boston is far the best city in America to live in, and seems to have taken up his abode here very pleasantly. His new book will be out the same day as the “Anthology”.

Why isn’t Ferris Greenslet publishing your “Solugob” translation? I thought he seemed inclined to take it when I spoke to him about it, but he said he was in correspondence with you, so I did nothing farther. Now somebody tells me that it is to be issued by Knopf. How stupid Houghton-Mifflin is, and what a number of opportunities they let go! Greenslet has absolutely spoiled his new poetry series by putting in everything – whether good or otherwise – for which the authors were willing to pay; with the result that the thing has no prestige as a series whatever.

I have seen the manuscript of Harriet’s “Anthology of New Poetry”, and I think she is going to have a very good volume there. Though it is not in all respects what I would have chosen, still it is excellent.

I get so homesick for you and Hilda sometimes that I really don’t know what to do. It seems a thousand years since I have been in London, and Fletcher and I have often said what we would not give to see you both. If it were not for Fletcher I should go crazy. He is the only person here with whose work I am in sympathy. With the others it is always making allowance in speech, trying to put oneself into their point of view for a moment. But Fletcher and I keep each other going. We have had some rather nice experiences lately; among others, one of the Harvard boys has written a long thesis on “Imagism” as his candidate’s essay for the Bowdoin English Literature Prize – and that’s something. Fletcher has seen a copy of it, which Aiken had, and says it was excellent. We do not know who the boy is, as these are submitted anonymously, but I am going to find out through my brother. He quoted a lot of my ideas, which I gave in my address to the boys out there this Winter, so I suppose he was in the audience. But it all proves we are getting ahead. Sometimes I get awfully discouraged, but I don’t suppose that is really necessary.

Who is Georges Turpin? He says he is a paroxyate, and sent me a book of his the other day. It is valuable to me chiefly because I did not know that my name was known at all in Paris; although Mr. Stanton’s little notice of the “Six French Poets” perhaps helped a little.

Please tell Hilda that rather an unfortunate thing has occurred because she sent Harriet a poem of hers – “The Shrine” – to print, and Harriet was accepting it, but in her usual dilatory fashion, she had not accepted it when I was in Chicago, and I informed her, with much regret, that the poem was in the forthcoming “Anthology”. She says she never received it until March, so I suppose Hilda must have got mixed as to what she had sent to us and what she was sending Harriet. I was awfully sorry to rob Hilda of the chance of selling it to Harriet, but it was too late for Harriet to print it before the “Anthology” came out, and we were already in the press. I tried to make Harriet take “The Pear Tree”, which was the only one of Hilda’s poems which had not been published which I had the manuscript of; but she thought she would rather ask Hilda to send her something else along the lines of “The Shrine”. It is too bad it occurred this way!
Let me know how you get on, and don’t leave me so long in silence – it will make me feel as though a planet had come along and chipped you off from the earth; don’t you remember Jules Verne’s story?

closer.p: Lots of love to you both.

div.note: Aldington ultimately publishes his book, Images, Old and New (1916), with Edmund R. Brown's press, Four Seas.
